data.title: Replacing OpenTK
data.body:
This stems from a discussion started in another PR:

https://github.com/mono/MonoGame/pull/4397#issuecomment-169345797

It has been over 3 years since we initially investigated sticking with OpenTK in MonoGame.  The OpenTK team at that time promised fixes and renewed development of the library.

Since then there have been improvements, but we still suffer problems with OpenTK functionality and need per-platform work arounds at times.

Is it finally time to give up on OpenTK?

Do we proceed with our own custom binding for SDL2 and OpenGL?

What happens to platforms like iOS and Android where we depend on the Xamarin fork of OpenTK for OpenGL access?

data.title: Fix Windows DesktopGL Window... again
data.body:
Fixes 2 things:
- Disables window centering code for Windows 8 and above
  - Windows 8 and above already has window centering
- Enables back border delay code for Windows
  - turns out if you switch fast enough fullscreen - window - fullscreen - window... you can get borderless window which is not fullscreen...

data.title: Dont use SDL with OpenTK on Windows
data.body:
This will affect DesktopGL Windows & Mac

@mrhelmut @dellis1972 Can you test this?

data.title: WindowsDX: Fixed "HasVibrationMotor" properties
data.body:
Fixes #4395 

The `SharpDX.XInput.CapabilityFlags.FfbSupported` (force-feedback) flag is not available in DirectX 11.0. However, it seems sufficient to just check the "motor speed" properties to determine if vibration is supported.

So this should work, but I was only able to test it with XInput gamepads which have vibration motors.

If anyone actually has an XInput controller which doesn't have vibration motors, then it would be awesome if you could test this and confirm that the `HasLeftVibrationMotor` and `HasRightVibrationMotor` properties both return the expected values.

data.title: GamePadCapabilities.HasLeftVibrationMotor / HasRightVibrationMotor  is wrong
data.body:
Hi,

I am using the latest nuget package from the develop feed 3.5.0967.
My Xbox 360 GamePad has both vibration motors, but the GamePadCapabilities return false on the corresponding HasLeft/RightVibrationMotor properties.
However i can set the vibration for both motors and they work just fine.

Is this already fixed in the current head?

Thanks and appreciation

data.body:
Let's improve the contributing guide to include some information for really new users:

  https://github.com/mono/MonoGame/blob/develop/CONTRIBUTING.md
- Links to info on how to use Git.
- Links to info on GitFlow and how we use GitHub.
- Explain and link to the `Help Wanted` issue tag.

We might even want to see about linking the contributing guide into the documentation generation.

data.title: Effects' MatrixTransform not set by SpriteBatch
OpenGL does not implicitly clear the depth buffer like DirectX does, causing random graphics corruption
data.body:
I had a game implemented which just immediately started blitting render targets (using a shader) to the primary back-buffer on each `Draw` run.  This worked absolutely fine under DirectX, but when running under OpenGL (on Mac, Linux or Android), I got seemingly random graphics corruption, like the following (but it could be much worse, with the back-buffer just containing random parts of the desktop):

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/504826/12111520/1031e684-b3ea-11e5-8c8a-2d9671bd0aa1.png)

This stumped me for ages, before someone suggested that the depth buffer was not being cleared.  In hindsight this makes sense - without the depth buffer being cleared, then OpenGL will leave it containing random garbage until it's written to after the back-buffer is initialized.  But nothing will pass the depth test to write to it because it's never been cleared.

DirectX does this by default and implicitly for you; the original code works fine on Windows.  However, I had to add right at the very start of my Draw loop, code like this:

``` csharp
renderContext.GraphicsDevice.Clear(
    ClearOptions.DepthBuffer, 
    Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Color.Transparent, 
    renderContext.GraphicsDevice.Viewport.MaxDepth,
    0);
```

Once I did that, OpenGL started working across all platforms again:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/504826/12111584/8a28e2a8-b3ea-11e5-86eb-606efcd383c9.png)

I believe for correctness sake, and for the purpose of making things work more correctly cross-platform out-of-the-box, MonoGame should implicitly perform this call for the developer.

What I'm not sure yet is whether this is just something we should do after initializing the back-buffer, or whether we need to do every frame.  I'd prefer a solution that was just the former in case the developer does want to preserve the depth buffer across frames (but obviously their game won't work under DirectX in that case).

data.title: Touch Controller does not work on Windows 10 using Windows.GL package
Fixes DPad not being processed in IsButtonDown / Up
data.body:
Fixes one of the issues reported in #4252.

Calling `GamePadState.IsButtonDown()` with any DPad buttons wasn't working.

data.title: Remove references to framework assemblies
data.body:
These references are automatically added by Protobuild based on the platform, so adding these references in external projects is unnecessary.  For Mac projects, this is actually detrimental, because the external project specifies MonoMac, even when the project will have a Xamarin.Mac reference added by Protobuild.

This also updates Protobuild, so it fixes those other outstanding issues (like the Windows Universal SDK versioning thing).

data.title: Add GetMaximumGamePadIndex API
data.body:
Fixes #4379

Adds a `GamePad.GetMaximumGamePadIndex` API so that games can safely enumerate game pads without catching InvalidOperationException

data.title: Missing public API to query maximum number of game pads
Implement Separating Axis Theorem
data.body: As I think it is relatively easy to solve for AABB and Sphere, this would really help to be in the main framework.

data.title: Change native binaries to be NativeBinary instead of None
data.body: This change the references of native binaries to use the `NativeBinary` reference in external projects instead of `None` with copy-on-output.  It's the same result for direct references, but it allows Protobuild to be smarter about adding copy-on-output entries when you reference a library that in turn references native binaries.

data.title: OpenTK requirements for gamepad support?
data.body:
Hello :)

It appears that gamepads are not working out of the box on MacOS. While we didn't had problems with most Linux distro, our Mac users can't use their gamepads (being Xbox360, PS3 or PS4) and the mono console prints "Number of joysticks: 0" when a game is started.

Does this have something to do with some missing dependencies? SDL?

data.title: Updating TargetPlatformVersion to latest SDK (November 2015)
data.body:
Fixes #4369

This sets the target version to the current SDK while maintaining backward compatibility for anyone who only has the RTM version of the SDK installed.
